title: CI topology
content:
With Native SACM enabled, the CI relationships of Actual Service, Device, Service Component, and System Element records are federated between Service Management and UCMDB.

CI relationships

Using the Native SACM solution, all relationships among these CIs are managed directly in UCMDB with the standard procedures UCMDB offers.

Note that it's no longer possible to use the Related CIs tab to create upstream and downstream relations among Actual Services, Service Components, System Elements, and Devices. However, you can use one of the following methods to manage CI relationships through the Service Management UI:

  • One option to build CI relations from the Service Management UI is to launch the UCMDB browser and use the assisted modeling to create your service model or the CI relations in the UCMDB Browser. For details, see UCMDB help center.
  • Use Studio business rules to create or delete three types (Composition, Containment, and Usage) of CI relationships. For details, see Related topics.
  • You can also use the Service Modeling feature on the Related CIs tab to create CI relationships directly. 

CI Topology widget

In Service Management, you can open a federated SACM record, click the Related CIs tab, and an embedded widget is displayed to visualize the topology as modeled in UCMDB. By default, only the directly related CIs will be displayed on the Related CIs tab.

With the CI Topology widget:

  • CIs of all federated CI types are displayed and can be drilled down to the CI details.
  • CIs of non-federated CI types are displayed in the widget as long as they are linked in UCMDB (included by UD/UCMDB TQL).
  • UCMDB CIs for SMA complex types such as CPU, File System, Disk Device, Interface, and IP address aren't displayed in the widget. The only exception is Running Software, which is displayed in the CI Topology.
  • For any missing CIs in SMA, caused by a CI federation issue or misoperation, an error message is displayed when you try to drill down to the CI details.
  • The CI Topology widget can display additional related CIs that are not visible by default. By updating the SMAX_Generic_Topology TQL, users can expand the topology and view more related CIs or services.
  • When a CI is at the last metaphase of the workflow, it won't be displayed on the Related CIs tab.

Service modeling

For users having the Service modeling permission in their user roles, the Related CIs window is open for editing with the service modeling feature. 

With this permission, when you enter the Related CIs window, a pane of available CIs is available on the left-hand side of the major CI relationship window. By default, this pane is collapsed; you can click ADD CI TO MAP to expand it. Through this pane, you can either search or expand the categories, select the CIs, and add them to the relationship window. Agents without this permission can only view and use the regular CI topology widget.

To display names in the dropdown list using the SMAX CI Type / UCMDB CI Type format, you must enable the UCMDB CI Type checkbox under Administration -> Studio -> SACM Settings (and select the desired SMAX CI Type in the top left dropdown, for example, System Element). When the checkbox is enabled, the selected CI Type will be federated; otherwise, if it is not enabled, only the UCMDB CI Type will appear in the dropdown.

CIs that meet the following two conditions are shown in this pane. 

  • The CI type has been set with the qualifier AVAILABLE_IN_MODELING_WIDGET_SACM in the UCMDB admin console. This qualifier can be customized. 

  • There is at least 1 CI instance of this CI type.

To create or edit CI relationships, follow these steps:

  1. On the Related CIs tab, expand ADD CI TO MAP.

  2. In the dropdown list, under Configuration Item section, select a record type and then select the CI(s) you want to add to the CI topology. Alternatively, use the search box to find the CI(s). A filter is available if you want to set conditions for the CIs to be displayed.

  3. Drag and drop the CI(s) to the CI topology main window on the right. 
  4. To create a relationship between two CI(s), press and hold the mouse cursor on the source CI, then move it to the target CI to create an arrow.
  5. Click the arrow and then click the pencil (Edit relationship) button.
  6. In the EDIT RELATIONSHIP window, choose a relationship. Note that only the available relationships appear in this window.
  7. Click Save on the top right.

To delete a relationship, follow these steps:

  1. In the CI topology main window on the right, click a CI or a relationship.
  2. Right-click a CI or a relationship.
  3. Click the Remove from map   icon. Alternatively, click the More icon on the top right, then click Remove from map. This will give a preview of the topology after the change.
    By clicking Remove from map, the CI or relationship simply disappears from the UI; no underlying data changes will be made to the database. Hence, the Save button can't be clicked.

  4. Once you have reviewed the changes and are sure to delete certain CI relationships from the database, refresh the browser.

  5. Select the relationship you want to delete, click Delete from database, and then click Save. Now, your changes take effect.

    Please be aware that the CIs can't be physically deleted through this window. Therefore, the Delete from database option doesn't appear if:
    • One or multiple CIs are selected.
    • CIs and relationships are both selected.

To change the view mode of CIs in CI topology, click the   or   icon on the top right to switch between Map View and Table View.

  • In Map View, you can visually see the hierarchical relationship of CIs.
  • In Table View, you can easily see the details of CIs and sort them based on each CI attribute in the column. All the CIs are grouped by the combination of SubType and CIType in the left panel.
    Currently, the field names in Table View are not localized.

    To export these CIs, click the  icon on the top right and choose the preferred format to download (CSV, PDF, or XLSX).

    To show or hide the attribute in the column, follow these steps:

    1. Go to UCMDB UI > CI Type Manager > CI Types.
    2. Select the specific CI Type under Configuration Item.
    3. On the Attributes tab, select one attribute as needed. 
    4. On the right pane, check or uncheck UCMDB CI Properties Layout and click Apply.
    5. Click Save on the top right.

Guided modeling

You can use model templates to guide the creation of CI topologies. A best practice modeling template ("SMAX Business Service Model") is provided out-of-the-box. Administrators can create new templates or modify the out-of-the-box template according to their organization's needs. Templates display the general CI structure (composed of CI types and potential relationships between them), onto which you can drag the relevant CIs and relationships to create the CI topology.

Users with Service modeling and Guided modeling only permissions can only use modeling templates. This permission takes effect only if you have installed UCMDB 25.4 or a later version.

To modify modeling templates (including the out-of-the-box "SMAX Business Service Model" template), log in to your UD/UCMDB local client. Click Modeling Studio > Resource > SMAXTopology, and then select the modeling template that you want to modify.

The "SMAX Business Service Model" modeling template is available in the CI Topology widget only if you have installed UD Content Pack 24.4 or a later version. 

To use guided modeling to create a CI topology, follow these steps:

  1. On the Related CIs tab, expand ADD CI TO MAP.
  2. In the Modeling template dropdown list, select the template that you want to follow. To quickly locate a template, you can filter the list by entering a text string in the drop-down list.

    The modeling topology map is displayed with the selected CI automatically loaded in the model.

  3. Add CIs to the model. To do this, follow these steps:

    1. In the left side panel, in the Configuration Item section, select a CI type from the dropdown list of available CI types. Only the CI types that match the selected template are displayed in the list. You can narrow down the list by using the search bar and filter.

    2. Drag the selected CI to the model. If you drag the CI to an empty area of the map, it is automatically placed in the corresponding CI type. You cannot place CIs inside different CI types on the map.  

  4. Add relationships to the model. To do this, press and hold the mouse cursor on the source CI, then move it to the target CI to create an arrow. You can only create relationships that follow the template's guidelines. These are marked with a dotted arrow. 

  5. Click Save on the top right.

To remove CI relationships from a CI topology while using guided modeling, follow the steps in the "Service modeling" section. 

Show non-federated CIs in the CI Topology widget

Some UCMDB CIs are not federated through Native SACM; however, you may have the need to show them in the CI Topology widget. This section takes a UCMDB CI type called CiCollection, for example, and describes how to allow it to appear in the CI Topology widget.

  1.  Log in to UCMDB local client, go to CI Type Manager > CiCollection > Qualifiers. Select and move the AVAILABLE_IN_MODELLINEG_WIDGET_SACM to the right panel. 
  2. Click Modeling Studio > Resource > SMAXTopology > SMAX_Generic_Topology/SMAX_Direct_Linked_CI. Add CiCollection into the Element Type as described in Update TQLs.
  3. In Service Management, click Related CIs of a Device CI. CiCollection can be seen on the CI type dropdown list, under Configuration Item.
     
  4. Click CiCollection. You can drag a CiColection CI to the right panel for service modeling purposes. The CI topology widget displays all directly linked CI collections with the current entry device and shows further linked CI collections for any selected CIs through the Show Related operation.

Filtering

You can use a filter based on UD/UCMDB CI type, Service Management Subtype, and CI instance name. For example:

The view will then only show the CIs matching the filter criteria. All other CIs are shown as part of the topology, but in a minimized display to allow the focus on the filtered CIs. 

Enabling “Hide Filtered Items” will remove the CIs that don't match the filter criteria. This view will then no longer present the end-to-end topology. Instead, it displays the starting CI and the CIs that match the filter, connected by a dotted line to indicate an indirect relationship to the starting CI. 

Impact Analysis

Impact Analysis can be done in 2 ways.

  • You can open Impact Analysis directly from the CI topology by clicking the button at the bottom of the menu. This option highlights the impacted CIs from the starting CI directly in the CI topology. 

  • In a SACM record type window, you can select a record and click the Show Impact button of Device/System Element records to view the CIs impacted by the selected record. If Native SACM is enabled, the CI topology will be displayed in a widget similar to the one on the Related CIs tab. Using this function will also show the impact of the affected CI. The difference is that this function shows a bottom-up view only of the directly impacted CIs. If Native SACM isn't enabled, by clicking the Show Impact button, the traditional widget of the impact topology (defined in Service Management only) will be displayed.

    The Show Impact button is also available to Incident, Request, Change, and Problem records. On the Involved CI tab, you can select an involved device or system element and click Show Impact to run impact analysis. 

Update TQLs 

On the UCMDB server side, some topologies have been created to support the federation into Service Management, including the CI relationship visualization. The current topologies can be found in the UCMDB modeling studio through Modeling Studio > Resources > Root > SMAXTopology.

Example 1. Update the TQLs in UCMDB and make the CiCollection fully visible in the widget

You need to update the TQLs in UCMDB and make the federation of CiCollection fully functional. Please follow these steps carefully:

  1. In UCMDB Admin UI, click Modeling Studio.
  2. Expand SMAXTopology.
  3. Double-click SMAX_Generic_Topology and make the following changes:
    1. Double-click InputCI, and the Query Node Properties window opens.
    2. In the Query Node Properties window, click the Element Type tab.
    3. In the CI Types tree, locate and click CiCollection. In the Condition drop-down list on the right, select Include <CiCollection> in the query. Make sure the By CI types and Apply this condition recursively on all subtypes of <xxx> options are selected.
    4. Click OK to save the changes.
    5. Double-click RelatedCI, and the Query Node Properties window opens.
    6. Repeat step b to step d above to make the same changes to the RelatedCI node.
    7. Double-click the Virtual_Input_to_related arrow between InputCI and RelatedCI, and the Add Compound Relationship window opens. 
    8. In the Add Compound Relationship window, select the first Configuration Item.
    9. Click the pencil icon next to Apply recursively:Yes under Source to open the Compound Relationship Condition Definition window.
    10. In the Compound Relationship Condition Definition window, click the Element Type tab.
    11. Repeat step b to step d above to make the same changes to the source of this Configuration Item.
    12. Click the pencil icon next to Apply recursively:Yes under Target to open the Compound Relationship Condition Definition window.
    13. In the Compound Relationship Condition Definition window, click the Element Type tab.
    14. Repeat step b to step d above to make the same changes to the target of this Configuration Item.
    15. In the Add Compound Relationship window, select the second Configuration Item.
    16. Repeat step i to step o to make the same changes to the second Configuration Item.
    17. Click OK to save the changes.
  4. Double-click SMAX_Direct_Linked_CI.
    1. Double-click Direct_Linked_CI, and the Query Node Properties window opens.
    2. Repeat step b to step d above to make the same changes to the Direct_Linked_CI node.

Example 2. Update the TQL in UCMDB and allow more related CIs to be displayed in the widget 

The value of Max steps in the SMAX_Generic_Topology TQL controls the level of CIs to be displayed in the CI Topology widget. By default, its value is 1, and only directly linked CIs from the entry CI are shown in the widget. If you want to have more levels of related CIs shown in the widget, follow these steps to update the TQL:

  1. In UCMDB Admin UI, click Modeling Studio > Resources.
  2. Expand SMAXTopology.
  3. Double-click SMAX_Generic_Topology and make the following changes:
    1. Double-click the Virtual_Input_to_related arrow between InputCI and RelatedCI, and the Add Compound Relationship window opens. 
    2. In the Add Compound Relationship window, change the value of Max steps to a proper number. For example, if you want to have 2 levels of related CIs shown in the widget, change its value to 2. 
    3. Click OK to save the changes.  
    4. Click Save to make the changes effective.
